From: Shane Duan <sduan@...>

I just checked the thread and realized that it is just what assertTrue(true)
brought up.  So please ignore my second reasoning.

-----Original Message-----
From: Shane Duan [mailto:sduan@...]
Sent: Monday, July 16, 2001 5:56 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] RE: Why doesn't JUnit count asserts?


Well, besides the lightweight-framework principle, I would have to
disagree because of the following two reasons:

1. If I create a testcase without any assertions, i would normally put a
System.out.println("Implement Me!"); in the test method, or a
fail("Implement Me!"), depending on the reason that I don't write
assertions.

2. sometimes, you just don't have assertions in the method.  For
example, the try-catch thread these days, there is not assertion and I
have been using the same pattern, e.g.

public void testException() throws Exception {
  try {
    ... // your code here
    fail("Exception Occurred!");
  }
  catch (ExpectedException ee) {}
}
subject: RE: [junit] RE: Why doesn't JUnit count asserts?
